6.55.text:
I'm Reza Pourkhomani,
founded Fivesky in October of 2012.

10.54.text:
It's been an interesting
almost three years for us.

12.93.text:
We're coming up on our third birthday
in about a week and a half from now.

15.58.text:
Fivesky is a services business
that focuses in the data center.

20.67.text:
We provide these services to some of
the larger enterprises around the world.

25.91.text:
I've been an entrepreneur
almost all my life,

28.13.text:
I remember my first company in college
where we had no idea how to even start

31.21.text:
a company,
let alone try to lead it and grow it.

34.02.text:
But since then throughout
all the experiences,

36.56.text:
we've looked at things that were exciting,
new, next gen for us.

39.89.text:
five sky was a little different
the really key factors for

44.04.text:
us to look at when we decided this
was where we were gonna go into.

47.66.text:
First and foremost I think it was really
important for us to identify a need

51.85.text:
that was big enough for us to go after and
we found that in the market.

54.64.text:
Secondly was my experience if you look
at our industry it's an ecosystem.

58.97.text:
Right?
And over the last 19 years I've had

61.34.text:
the pleasure of being in different
sections of that ecosystem.

64.15.text:
>From being the customer being the engineer
who had to deliver the work to

67.38.text:
the customer,
being the grumpy salesperson,

69.94.text:
all the way through
working at a manufacturer.

71.59.text:
So I thought having sat
in every part of this,

74.28.text:
I can kind of bring it together in a way
that it hadn't done before, right?

78.14.text:
Look at it from all the things I
hated when I was a customer and

81.24.text:
all the things I hated when I was I was an
engineer and I said, if I solve those then

84.44.text:
I'm building something that
brings a new way of innovating

87.98.text:
to all these groups that we are involved
with and that was really big for us.

91.60.text:
The third defining point for us was that
it's an industry that we can scale in.

95.67.text:
Specifically, if you look
at services industries,

97.88.text:
most of the time companies are started and
they play in the market they live in.

103.08.text:
So, as a small start up they're
providing services to the SMB market

107.02.text:
as their industry, as their business close
they're going after larger industries.

111.50.text:
Here we looked at it and
saw the ability for

114.52.text:
us to be able to go after some
of the larger customers and

118.48.text:
dust enable us to grow really rapidly
which has been a key successful for us.

123.27.text:
I'm fortunate to say that some of
the biggest learning experiences have been

127.48.text:
The bigger the failure, I think the bigger
the learning experience has been and

130.59.text:
although at the time it might
not feel very pleasant.

133.07.text:
But the next time you travel that
road you've gained this level of

136.01.text:
confidence that I think
would be unachievable or

138.57.text:
unattainable any other way than
having gone that road before.

141.67.text:
I knew that we need to have
a supporting ecosystem, a mentor.

145.91.text:
As a single person starting this company,
I knew I needed to go seek help and

150.35.text:
through some research, a close
friend of mine who's a professor at

153.77.text:
Colombia had suggested that
I meet with the SBDC office.

157.39.text:
I wrote them an email, I really
didn't think much about it, but I was

160.79.text:
pleasantly surprised to have got an email
twice as long as the email I sent back.

164.44.text:
And that kind of opened
up the connection for me.

166.69.text:
>From the very first meeting which I had
with them, just about three years ago,

170.45.text:
when we had just started
Fivesky until now.

172.68.text: Not only a mentor, but an enabler for us.

176.38.text:
I remember my very first meeting qll
we talked about was the other five or

180.28.text:
ten entrepreneurs that they had met with
that week and some of their problems.

183.55.text:
They weren't my problems but it was nice
to know there are others with problems,

187.11.text: and that they're working through it and

188.98.text:
there's this whole world that
exists that I'm part of.

191.57.text:
And that kinda gives you the confidence to
say, well, if this guy has this problem,

195.82.text:
mine doesn't seem suddenly so
bad and I can go achieve it.

198.59.text:
The second value that has
been very tremendous for

202.01.text:
us has been their ability
to be an enabler.

204.85.text:
Every time we come up to a road that
we haven't crossed in the past and

208.38.text:
it's completely new landscape for us,
we've been able to go to them and

211.74.text:
get direction Gain understanding
about some other people have done.

217.06.text:
They were more than helpful,
and more than knowledgeable

220.14.text:
in the areas in which we needed help and
if they didn't, they knew who was.

223.51.text:
What was important for us was to be able
to have someone who understands what we

226.87.text:
are going through and that can, kind of,
point you into the right direction.

229.92.text: Sometimes it wasn't the right direction,

231.42.text:
it was many directions that they pointed
us but it was better than no direction.

239.00.text:
I think the two biggest
things that come to mind is.

242.63.text:
Do it.
I think that's really important.

245.76.text:
I have fans that come out with brilliant
ideas and the next time I see them,

248.95.text:
its the same brilliant idea,
its just a little less brilliant.

251.81.text:
Everyday it becomes less and
less if you don't do it.

254.22.text:
The second thing which more specifically,
I've seen around a lot of text start-ups,

258.63.text:
smaller text start-up is that,
they're trying to build this dream.

262.14.text:
And, if you look at the first lamborghini,
it wasn't a lamborghini.

265.50.text: It was a car that drove.

266.87.text:
It went forward and made some turns and
it had a lot of problems.

269.95.text:
Even if you go back 20 years from now,
it still wasn't a refined machine, but

273.83.text:
it constantly adopted and
evolved and grew.

276.64.text:
It's unfortunate when I see
some of these start ups get

280.18.text:
really focused down to their future
functionality and these little things,

284.28.text:
and they really haven't thought
about some of the bigger things,

286.84.text:
and they're trying to focus on getting
all the little things sorted out.

290.59.text:
I think having the shortest path
to success at the beginning is

296.05.text:
People want to take a step back and
build the best, greatest,

299.72.text: and awesomest things that will come.

301.90.text:
If you have the idea, you have the right
theme, and the passion, it will be back.

306.53.text:
Don't loose sight through the process and
prolong things and

309.84.text: be afraid of enter the market.

311.26.text:
Go into market, get slapped come back,
redo it, and go do it again.

315.30.text:
I think that's the fastest,
most efficient way to success.
